QuestionText.Text: I ____ like to cook.
Jack is ____ student in his class.
____ are beautiful flowers in my garden.

They are ____ meet us for coffee this afternoon.

Making a decision without first thinking carefully can have serious ____.

Our teacher is great. We ____ see her get angry or upset.

Material.Text: The woman is in the store buying fruit for breakfast.

QuestionText.Text: What is true about the students?

AnswerSentence.Text: They saw animals in a report.

Material.Text: The students took a trip to the zoo to study animals for a report they are writing.

He wanted Eric to work late.

Material.Text: Eric stayed late at the office so he could finish the report that his boss asked him to write.

AnswerSentence.Text: She wasn’t able to go shopping.
She stayed home with her friends.

Material.Text: Janet and her friends wanted to go shopping on the weekend, but she had so much homework that she had to stay home.

AnswerSentence.Text: She is in the post office.

Material.Text: The restaurant added more sandwiches and salads to its menu, but they have not been very popular with customers.

AnswerSentence.Text: He is spending more time at work.
He is working toward a promotion.

Material.Text: After getting promoted to his new position, Charles started coming to work earlier every morning and gave up his long Wednesday lunches.

AnswerSentence.Text: Its location is convenient for all.

Material.Text: The enormous shopping mall that is about to open on the south side of town is loved and hated in almost equal measure by local residents.

QuestionText.Text: What did Paul do?

AnswerSentence.Text: He met friends instead of working.

He worked instead of having lunch.

Material.Text: Paul went out for lunch with his friends when he should have been working on his presentation.

QuestionText.Text: Why did the woman ask the man a question?

AnswerSentence.Text: She didn't understand what he said.
She would like more time to decide.
She thought he gave her the wrong food.

Material.Text:

Woman: Sorry, what kind of what?
Man: What kind of meat do you want? We have regular chicken, spicy chicken, and lamb.

QuestionText.Text: Why does the man apologize?

AnswerSentence.Text: He will be late for the party.
He forgot to invite the neighbors.
He didn't bring anything to the barbecue.

Material.Text:
W: Hey, Rob! The neighbors should be getting to my place around 6 tomorrow for the barbecue. Any chance you could swing by earlier in the day to help me get everything set up?
M: [hesitantly] About tomorrow... I’m really sorry… I know I told you that I'd be free this weekend, but something’s come up...
W: [disappointed] Oh. Well, some other time, then!

QuestionText.Text: Why is the woman annoyed?

AnswerSentence.Text: They don't have an up-to-date user's guide.
The man didn't finish writing the user's guide.
She can't find a user's guide.
She doesn't understand the user's guide.

Material.Text:
Woman: Please don't tell me that this is the most recent user's guide that we have.
Man: I think it is. Why?
Woman: It was printed in two-thousand-seven.
Man: Well, I can check around but I'm sure that's it.

QuestionText.Text: Why does the man repeat the names of the side dishes?

AnswerSentence.Text: He is trying to decide which to order.
He doesn't know what the options are.
He didn't hear all of the options.
He is going to order more than one of them.

Material.Text:
Woman: So, the chicken sandwich that you ordered comes with a side. Which one do you want?
Man: Oh. What are the options?
Woman: You can get French fries, sweet potato fries, coleslaw, or potato salad. Or just a regular salad.
Man: Regular salad, potato salad, coleslaw, or fries. I see.
Woman: Or sweet potato fries.

QuestionText.Text: What is true about the speakers?

AnswerSentence.Text: They are worried about their meeting.
They have been given a difficult assignment.
They have to present an idea to their boss.
They don't want to reschedule their meeting.

Material.Text:
Woman: It's not like Jack to call a meeting like this with no warning. Do you have any idea what it's about?
Man: I know as much as you do. First I heard about this was when I got that ominously worded email twenty minutes ago.

QuestionText.Text: How does the man react to the woman's comment about his desk?

AnswerSentence.Text: He disagreed that it is messy.
He compared it to her desk.

Material.Text:
Woman: Wow, Frank, would it kill you to tidy up your desk a bit?
Man: Well, I always say "a tidy desk is a sign of an empty mind."
Woman: That's such a cliché. All I know is that it takes you ten minutes to find anything. And it's turning into an eyesore.

Section 5.1 Reimbursements

The company reimburses employees for all costs related to business travel. These include, but are not limited to, airfare or other transportation to a destination; local travel at the destination, such as taxi fare, car rental, or public transportation; lodging; communication and technology fees (Wi-Fi, telephone calls); and meals and entertainment. Meal costs may not exceed the per diem rates set forth in Section 5.3.3. Exceptions may occasionally be made for certain client meetings. Other qualified expenses include professional membership or event fees related to conference registration.

Non-reimbursable expenses include preventable flight cancellation or change fees and personal expenses, such as personal excursions or meals shared with friends or family. Expenses such as laundry and gym are covered but only for extended travel (see Section 5.3.4) or when approved beforehand by a supervisor.

QuestionText.Text: What is the purpose of Section 5.1?

AnswerSentence.Text: to specify what travel expenses a company will pay for
to identify ways to reduce business travel expenses
to show how much a company spends on business travel
to explain how to request reimbursement for travel expenses

QuestionText.Text: What exception may be made for employees?

AnswerSentence.Text: Participation at conferences may be supported.
Tours to local destinations may be included.
Special trips to visit clients may be required.

QuestionText.Text: What is Section 5.3.4 probably about?

Material.Text:
Jessica has just a few hours left to finish an important proposal. She has well-crafted and compelling arguments and the right data to support them, but she has no tables or graphs. She could ask her colleague Paul to help create the visuals she needs; however, she worries he might think that she can’t do her job.

Sound familiar? We all have, at one time or another, avoided asking for help for fear that people would judge us. However, some experts say that rather than driving people away, requesting assistance can help build relationships. By asking a colleague to help complete a difficult task, you show that you think that person has valuable skills. By generously lending a helping hand, your colleague feels a sense of accomplishment. And as you collaborate in completing the task, you develop teamwork skills.

QuestionText.Text: What problem does Jessica have?

AnswerSentence.Text: She can’t design visuals for her proposal.
She can’t finish her proposal by the deadline.
She thinks Paul doesn’t appreciate her work.
She doesn’t work well with others in her office.

QuestionText.Text: Based on paragraph 2, what will likely happen if Paul helps Jessica?

AnswerSentence.Text: He will feel a sense of self-worth.
He will think less of her abilities.
She will ask him for too many favors.

QuestionText.Text: What advice would the author of this text probably give Jessica?
To minimize ____ while he was studying, George turned off his phone and closed the door to his room.
The ____ of Katherine's writing makes her news articles enjoyable and easy to read regardless of the topic.
Don't ____ until tomorrow what you can do today.
Because of the authorities' quick response, the disease has been ____ to a small region in the southern part of the country.
The band's big ____ came when they performed as the opening act at the extremely popular Wellington Music Festival.
The firing of the CEO was an unfortunate ____ we will not soon forget.
The number of attendees at Jack's retirement party was ____ to how valued he was as an employee.
The two recent oil spills were the ____ for the new environmental regulations.
Without a doubt, the ____ difference between our companies is customer service.
Consumers need to act ____ on this offer because it will expire soon.
Given the serious doubts about the long-term ____ of the airport in its current state, the government is proposing a major renovation.

AnswerSentence.Text: The man completed his timesheet incorrectly.
The company is unhappy with the man’s work.
The man forgot to contact the payroll department.
The bank made a financial mistake.

Material.Text:

W: Yeah, it was a couple of days ago. Why?
M: Hmm. I thought so, but nothing showed up in my bank account. I wonder if I did something wrong, or if it was the payroll department.
W: Well, I know if your timesheet has information missing, you don't get paid until it's fixed.

Material.Text:

W: I did all of the assigned reading before class, but I got lost there at the end too.
M: Yeah, I think she's getting ahead of herself.

as a complaint about how cold the room is

AnswerSentence.Text: how much food the man is buying
how much sauce the man made

Material.Text:

Man: Oh, just make some sauce.
Woman: For a small army?
Man: Oh, no, this will last me three or four months, at least.

QuestionText.Text: What does the woman tell the man?

Material.Text:

Material.Text:

Woman: That's not surprising. Jerry thinks of himself as a big picture thinker—those kind of details are beneath him.
Man: Even though he's the production manager?

QuestionText.Text: What does the woman's comment indicate?

AnswerSentence.Text: She thinks the report is overly negative.
She agrees that Sam made a mistake in the report.

She thinks Sam is a poor writer.

Material.Text:
Man: According to the latest report from Sam, our sales with young people are still pretty dismal.
Woman: Yeah, I saw that he emphasized that. Even though overall sales are up for the third straight quarter.

From mountain hikes to beach lounging, there is no shortage of ways to appreciate nature. In Japan, one outdoor activity has a word dedicated to it: “hanami,” which translates literally to “flower viewing.” Hanami is something of a national pastime. Each spring, the nation gathers to celebrate the arrival of the year’s cherry blossoms. In parks throughout the country, families, friends, and couples spend the day enjoying food, company, and, of course, the blossoms themselves. The flowers’ appearance generally coincides with the end of the fiscal and school year, and those breaks create the perfect opportunity for celebration and relaxation. Hanami is not exclusive to Japan. Other regions of the world with concentrated cherry tree populations partake in annual celebrations as far away as Brooklyn, NY, and Washington, DC, in the United States.

QuestionText.Text: What is the purpose of this text?

AnswerSentence.Text: to describe a popular cultural tradition
to define a newly created Japanese word
to compare celebrations around the world
to discuss tourists’ favorite activity in Japan

QuestionText.Text: What can be expected of school children in Japan during hanami?

AnswerSentence.Text: They picnic with their class under cherry trees.
They bring cherry blossoms home from school.

QuestionText.Text: What does the author highlight about the United States?

AnswerSentence.Text: It has cherry tree orchards in remote regions.
Its Japanese immigrants maintain their traditions.

Material.Text:
Memorandum

To: South Campus Dormitory Residents

On several occasions recently, unregistered guests have been found unaccompanied after the permitted hours. As a reminder, all persons at the dormitory must have a valid resident or staff identification card. Unregistered guests are not allowed under any circumstances.

To obtain a guest pass, residents must submit advance notification online, and guests must show valid identification upon arrival. Guests must be accompanied by a resident or staff member at all times. Guests are permitted between the hours of 7 a.m. and midnight seven days a week. Written agreement must be obtained in advance from all cohabitants of the host’s shared space for overnight stays.

Hosts are responsible for the conduct of their guests, including liability for any damage or violations. Nonresidents are prohibited from using student services or amenities, such as dining hall meals, fitness room, or onsite parking.

QuestionText.Text: Why did dormitory residents receive this memorandum?

AnswerSentence.Text: Regulations for guest visits have been changed.
New dormitory residents have arrived on campus.
Dormitory residents have been issued new ID cards.

QuestionText.Text: According to the text, what would require permission from a resident’s roommates?
According to paragraph 3, what is true about hosts?

AnswerSentence.Text: They will be charged if their guests cause problems.
They must pay for their guests’ meals at the dining hall.
Their guests must be dormitory residents.
Their guests have limited access to student services.
